title: Write VISION.md
description:
## Required Reading
- .claude/rules/vision-format.md (format rule)
- .claude/rules/documentation-standards.md (writing style)
- .claude/rules/promt.md (Cupboard/Table design brief)
- Bootstrap description in .claude/commands/bootstrap.md

## Files to Create
- docs/VISION.md

## Requirements

Write VISION.md per vision-format rule.

Cobbler is NOT a coding agent or a planning agent. It is a dispatch layer that sits above agents. It prepares context, selects work from a crumbs cupboard, builds focused prompts, and hands off to specialized agents. A coding agent codes. A planning agent plans. Cobbler makes sure each agent gets exactly the context it needs and nothing more, so agents spend tokens on what they are good at rather than on orienting themselves, reading project state, or managing task lifecycle.

Agents are plug-and-play. Cobbler defines an agent interface; any LLM backend that implements it can be swapped in. This separates the concern of "what work needs doing and what context does it need" from "which model executes it."

Cobbler replaces prototype bash scripts (scripts/make-work.sh and scripts/do-work.sh) with a proper Go tool that has direct cupboard access via the crumbs Go module, structured prompt templates, and a real agent interface.

The command set uses shoemaking metaphors mapped to autogenic self-* capabilities:

| Self-capability | Command | What it does |
|----------------|---------|-------------|
| Self-orienting | cobbler measure | Assess project state, propose tasks |
| Self-programming | cobbler stitch | Dispatch coding agent to execute work |
| Self-reflecting | cobbler inspect / cobbler mend | Evaluate output, dispatch agent to fix issues |
| Self-architecting | cobbler pattern | Dispatch agent to propose design changes |

Sections to write:
1. Executive Summary: cobbler is a dispatch layer above AI agents, not an agent itself. It connects to a crumbs cupboard, prepares context, and hands off to specialized agents. Four self-* capabilities (self-orienting, self-programming, self-reflecting, self-architecting). It is not a task tracker, IDE plugin, or CI system.
2. Introduction: context (AI agents are good at specific things - coding, planning - but waste tokens on orientation, context-gathering, and task management when left to do everything). Problem (letting an agent do everything is token-inefficient and conflates concerns; prototype bash scripts work but do not scale). What cobbler does (separates dispatch from execution; prepares focused prompts so agents spend tokens on their specialty).
3. Why this project: fills the gap between task storage (crumbs) and agent execution. Token efficiency through separation of concerns. Plug-and-play agent swapping. Graduates prototype scripts into a real tool.
4. Planning and Implementation: success criteria (agents complete doc and code tasks with focused prompts; agent backends are swappable), phases table (01.0 stitch docs, 02.0 stitch code, 03.0 measure, 04.0 inspect/mend/pattern), risks table.
5. What This Is NOT: not a coding agent (agents code; cobbler dispatches). Not a planning agent (agents plan; cobbler prepares). Not a task tracker (use crumbs). Not an IDE plugin. Not a CI system. Not fully autonomous (humans approve measure output before stitch executes).

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All required sections per vision-format present
- [ ] Clear that cobbler is a dispatch layer, not an agent
- [ ] Token efficiency rationale explained
- [ ] Plug-and-play agent swapping described
- [ ] Autogenic self-* capabilities and command mapping explained
- [ ] Origin story: replaces make-work.sh and do-work.sh prototype scripts
- [ ] Style follows documentation-standards (active voice, no forbidden terms, royal we)
- [ ] File saved as docs/VISION.md

title: Write ARCHITECTURE.md
description:
## Required Reading
- docs/VISION.md (written in prior issue)
- .claude/rules/architecture-format.md (format rule)
- .claude/rules/documentation-standards.md (writing style)
- .claude/rules/promt.md (Cupboard/Table design brief)
- Crumbs docs: /Users/petardjukic/WORKSPACE/crumbs/docs/ARCHITECTURE.md (cupboard/table interfaces)
- Crumbs PRDs: /Users/petardjukic/WORKSPACE/crumbs/docs/product-requirements/ (interface contracts)

## Files to Create
- docs/ARCHITECTURE.md

## Requirements

Write ARCHITECTURE.md per architecture-format rule. Describe how cobbler is built: components, interfaces, data flow, and design decisions.

Cobbler is a dispatch layer, not an agent. It sits between the cupboard (work item storage) and agents (LLM backends). Cobbler's job is to prepare context and build focused prompts so agents spend tokens on their specialty (coding, planning, etc.) rather than on orienting themselves. The architecture must reflect this separation: cobbler handles work selection, context gathering, prompt construction, and lifecycle management. Agents handle execution.

Cobbler replaces prototype scripts (scripts/make-work.sh -> measure, scripts/do-work.sh -> stitch) with a Go tool.

Commands map to self-* capabilities:

| Self-capability | Command | What it does |
|----------------|---------|-------------|
| Self-orienting | cobbler measure | Assess project state, propose tasks |
| Self-programming | cobbler stitch | Dispatch coding agent to execute work |
| Self-reflecting | cobbler inspect / cobbler mend | Evaluate output, dispatch agent to fix |
| Self-architecting | cobbler pattern | Dispatch agent to propose design changes |

Sections to write:
1. System Overview: cobbler is a dispatch layer between crumbs cupboard and pluggable agents. It does not execute work itself - it prepares context and dispatches to agents. Lifecycle of a work item through cobbler (ready -> claimed -> context gathered -> prompt built -> agent dispatched -> quality gate -> closed). Coordination pattern: pull-based (cobbler queries cupboard for ready crumbs).
2. Main interfaces: Cupboard integration (import crumbs Go module, Cupboard.GetTable(name).Get/Set pattern), Agent interface (pluggable - any LLM backend that implements Run can be swapped in; start with Claude), Executor interface (claim, build context, dispatch agent, close loop). The agent interface is the plug-and-play boundary.
3. System Components: CLI (cobra, commands: measure, stitch, inspect, mend, pattern), Config (viper), Measure (reads docs/roadmap/cupboard, proposes crumbs - replaces make-work.sh), Executor/Stitch (gathers context, builds prompt, dispatches agent - replaces do-work.sh), Agent (LLM abstraction with pluggable backends; Claude impl via anthropic-sdk-go), Prompt Builder (templates that focus agent tokens on the task, not on orientation), Crumbs Client (thin wrapper around imported crumbs Go module).
4. Design Decisions: (a) cobbler dispatches, agents execute - separation of concerns for token efficiency, (b) agent interface is the plug-and-play boundary - swap backends without changing dispatch logic, (c) import crumbs as Go module not CLI wrapper, (d) prompt templates minimize agent token spend on orientation, (e) commands named after shoemaking terms mapped to autogenic self-* capabilities.
5. Technology Choices: Go, cobra, viper, crumbs module (github.com/petar-djukic/crumbs), anthropic-sdk-go.
6. Project Structure: cmd/cobbler/, pkg/ (agent, planner, executor, crumbs), internal/ (prompt, config, claude).
7. Implementation Status: phase 01.0 focus is cobbler stitch --docs.

## Design Decisions
- Cobbler is dispatch, not execution: it prepares context and prompts, agents do the work
- Agent interface is the plug-and-play boundary: any LLM backend can be swapped in
- Prompt templates are designed for token efficiency: give agents focused context, not everything
- Cupboard accessed via imported Go module (github.com/petar-djukic/crumbs)
- Command names from shoemaking trade mapped 1:1 to autogenic self-* capabilities

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All required sections per architecture-format present
- [ ] Clear that cobbler is dispatch layer, agents are pluggable executors
- [ ] Agent interface described as the plug-and-play boundary
- [ ] Token efficiency rationale in design decisions
- [ ] Command set (measure, stitch, inspect, mend, pattern) documented with self-* mapping
- [ ] Design decisions numbered with rationale
- [ ] Technology choices table present
- [ ] Project structure directory tree present
- [ ] Style follows documentation-standards
- [ ] File saved as docs/ARCHITECTURE.md

title: Write ROADMAP.yaml
description:
## Required Reading
- docs/VISION.md (written in prior issue)
- .claude/rules/use-case-format.md (release numbering scheme)

## Files to Create
- docs/ROADMAP.yaml

## Requirements

Write ROADMAP.yaml as a YAML file defining the release schedule and use case status for cobbler.

Commands use shoemaking terms mapped to autogenic self-* capabilities:
- measure (self-orienting): assess state, propose tasks
- stitch (self-programming): execute work via agents
- inspect (self-reflecting): show project state
- mend (self-reflecting): fix tests and lint
- pattern (self-architecting): propose design changes

Releases:
- 00.0: Cross-release milestones (spans multiple releases)
- 01.0: Core stitch (docs) - cobbler stitch --docs working end-to-end
  - Use cases: cupboard connection, doc task execution, agent loop
- 02.0: Core stitch (code) - cobbler stitch --code working
  - Use cases: code task execution, quality gates (test, lint)
- 03.0: Measure - cobbler measure working (replaces make-work.sh)
  - Use cases: project analysis, work proposal, crumb creation
- 04.0: Inspect, mend, and pattern - remaining self-* capabilities
  - Use cases: project state display, test/lint fix loop, design proposals
- 99.0: Unscheduled

Each release entry should include: focus description, list of use cases with status (planned/in-progress/done), and deliverables.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] YAML is valid and parseable
- [ ] All releases listed with focus, use cases, and deliverables
- [ ] Commands use revised names (measure, stitch, inspect, mend, pattern)
- [ ] Release numbering matches use-case-format convention (NN.N)
- [ ] File saved as docs/ROADMAP.yaml
